author: bridge-bot
content:
<timbeiko> Thanks for sharing!
Definitely need to think about this more, but a few initial thoughts: 
- I think we‚Äôve tried hard to avoid committing to timelines publicly, caveating them when we do, and also having documents which explain what‚Äôs still todo (e.g. the readiness checklist). It‚Äôs a fine line between sharing progress as it‚Äôs done and also making it clear that ‚Äúunknown unknowns‚Äù are very real.if we find a bad bug even 1 week before we go live, we will have to delay. Suggestions welcome about how we can communicate this better!
- We have started approaching end users and applications/infra to get them to use the devnets, Kintsugi being the latest. Our ‚Äústrategy‚Äù has been to try and grow the number of stakeholders involved in each iteration, but we are getting towards more stable ones where it‚Äôd be nice to see more professional use. 
- as for comms/PR, we currently have the Ethereum blog, where we share major updates, my blog where I share more in-progress ones, and various ad-hoc channels. Is there anything else you think we should have? More stuff on the Ethereum.org blog?

author: bridge-bot
content: <dannyryan> We‚Äôve also done two community calls, no? with plans of more as kintsugi stablizes and we have a firmer testnet/testing plan?

author: vorot93
content: Noob question for eth2 folks: why are integers fixed width in SSZ?

author: yperbasis
content: What's the link for the CL call?

author: sky.cactus
content: Speculation: simplicity, and in many cases widths aren't particularly variable so there is no (or sometimes negative) savings by having variable width.  A timestamp, for example, won't have a high variability in width.

author: sky.cactus
content: It does require more care with picking appropriate widths though.

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, I think you can throw a compression layer on top of SSZ and get much of the benefit of variable width encoders.

author: ajsutton
content: And indeed we use snappy compression for communication between peers.

author: sky.cactus
content: Out of curiosity, has anyone compared compression of real-world data between SSZ + snappy vs RLP + snappy?

author: ajsutton
content: I know there was some analysis done on how effective snappy compression was for typical gossip messages but not sure where that was or if anything similar has been done for RLP. I'm guessing it was done for RLP at some point because I think an eth protocol update introduced snappy compression so I'm guessing there was some evidence it actually helped.
